div1.p:
Spec orders Vol 2 - 1900
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Carroll

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
NO. 247. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, October 20, 1900.

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private August P.
Linquist, Company A, 13th Infantry, now at the Presidio of
San Francisco, California, is transferred as a 2d class private
to the Signal Corps. He will be sent to Fort McDowell, Cali-
fornia, and will report upon arrival to the commanding officer
for duty with the Signal Corps detachment at that post.

2. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Thomas E.
Murnane, jr., Battery B, 1st Artillery, now in confinement at
Fort McPherson, Georgia, will be discharged without honor
from the Army by the commanding officer of his station, by
reason of his own misconduct. This soldier is not entitled to
travel-pay.

3. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Fred E.
Pierce, Battery G, 7th Artillery, Fort Warren, Massachusetts,
will be discharged without honor from the Army by the com-
manding officer of his station, by reason of his own miscon-
duct. This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.

4. By direction of the Secretary of War, Recruit John
Ryan, general service, now at the recruiting station, No.
57 East 125th street, New York City, having enlisted under
false pretences, will be discharged without honor from the
Army by the officer in charge of that station. Under para-
graph 1386 of the Regulations this soldier is not entitled to
pay or allowances, and final statements will not be furnished
him.

5. By direction of the Secretary of War, Private Frank K.
Volk, Company F, 5th Infantry, Fort Sheridan, Illinois, will
be discharged without honor from the Army by the command-
ing officer of his station, by reason of his own misconduct.
This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.

6. By direction of the Secretary of War, a board of survey
to consist of--

Major Charles Shaler, Ordnance Department, U. S. Army,
is appointed to meet at Indianapolis Arsenal, Indianapolis,
Indiana, October 24, 1900, or as soon thereafter as practicable,
2
for the purpose of investigating, reporting upon, and fixing
the responsibility for certain ordnance and ordnance stores for
which Major Charles H. Noble, 25th U. S. Infantry, is re-
sponsible.

7. First Lieutenant George C. Saffarrans, 10th U. S. Infan-
try, now on leave of absence, will proceed to Fort Thomas,
Kentucky, and report in person to the commanding officer for
duty at that post until further orders. The travel enjoined is
necessary for the public service.

8. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Captain
William C. Dow, 43d Infantry, U. S. Volunteers, having ar-
rived in San Francisco, California, in obedience to paragraph
4, Special Orders, No. 132, September 7, 1900, Division of the
Philippines, will proceed to his home preparatory to his dis-
charge from the service of the United States. The travel en-
joined is necessary for the public service.

9. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Major
Joseph S. Wilkins, additional paymaster, U. S. Volunteers,
having arrived in San Francisco, California, as directed by
Special Orders, No. 140, September 16, 1900, Division of the
Philippines, will repair to this city and report in person to the
Adjutant General of the Army for instructions. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

10. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Major
James W. Pope, quartermaster, U. S. Army, acting purchas-
ing commissary, Denver, Colorado, will make not to exceed
three visits each month during the fiscal year ending June 30,
1901, to such points in the vicinity of Denver, Colorado, as may
be necessary, on official business pertaining to the inspection
of subsistence stores, and on completion of this duty will re-
turn to his proper station after each visit. The travel en-
joined is necessary for the public service.

11. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the leave of
absence on surgeon's certificate of disability granted Acting
Assistant Surgeon James Carroll, U. S. Army, in Special
Orders, No. 178, October 10, 1900, headquarters, Division of
Cuba, is extended ten days.
✓

12. By direction of the Secretary of War, the extension of
leave of absence on surgeon's certificate of disability granted
Captain Robert L. Brown, assistant quartermaster, U. S. Vol-
3
unteers, in Special Orders, No. 208, September 5, 1900, from this
office, is further extended one month on account of sickness.

13. The extension of leave of absence granted 1st Lieutenant
Edmund M. Leary, 2d U. S. Cavalry, in Special Orders, No. 152,
September 3, 1900, Division of Cuba, is further extended ten
days.

14. Under instructions from the President, 2d Lieutenant
Guy A. Boyle, 30th Infantry, U. S. Volunteers, having ten-
dered his resignation, is honorably discharged from the service
of the United States by the Acting Secretary of War, to take
effect November 1, 1900. He will proceed to his home. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

15. By direction of the President, 2d Lieutenant Clifton R.
Berry, signal officer, U. S. Volunteers, is honorably discharged
by the Acting Secretary of War from the service of the United
States on account of physical disability, to take effect Novem-
ber 1, 1900. Lieutenant Berry will proceed to his home. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF LIEUTENANT GENERAL MILES:

H. C. CORBIN,
Adjutant General.
